Award.AwardTitle: Enumeration Problems in Algebraic Geometry and Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project concerns both algebraic geometry, which seeks to characterize solutions to algebraic equations with geometry, and representation theory, which is a systematic investigation of symmetry. Despite their abstract nature, the answers to many questions in both of these subjects boil down to being able to compute certain numbers. The purpose of this research project is to use new techniques from algebraic geometry and commutative algebra to recast these numbers as combinatorial quantities, making them easier to understand with a computer. By utilizing conceptual connections to other scientific fields, this research will also advance the understanding of several questions in mathematical physics and mathematical biology. Undergraduate students are involved directly as collaborators in the project, providing them with training in advanced mathematical topics and the use of 3D printing techniques in mathematical research.

The algebraic geometry of moduli spaces of principal bundles and branching varieties naturally produces two interesting enumeration problems: counting branching multiplicities of a map of reductive groups, and finding the dimension of the spaces of conformal blocks from the Wess-Zumino-Novikov-Witten model of conformal field theory. This research aims to further understanding of these quantities using the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies and the quickly evolving field of Berkovich geometry. These theories will be used to provide new polyhedral descriptions of conformal blocks and branching multiplicities, as well as further the understanding of the topology and symplectic geometry of the spaces under consideration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific component of this project had two goals:

First, to understand specific pieces of geometry and combinatorics pertaining to complex reductive symmetry groups. 

Second, to develop computational and combinatorial tools for broader applications in commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, and symplectic geometry.  Specifically, to develop the theory of toric degeneration of algebraic varieties.

A number of research projects and collaborations benefitted from this award.

The basic technology for degenerating algebras of conformal blocks associated to smooth curves to closely related algebras defined using singular stable curves.  I find presentation and structural commutative algebra results in the case SL_2, and for certain subalgebras in the case SL_m.  Part of this work was developing the discovery that conformal blocks can be related to the geometry and combinatorics of character varieties. 

 

C. Manon The algebra of conformal blocks, J. Eur. Math. Soc. (JEMS), Electronically published 9/6/18, doi:10.4171/JEMS/822 (to appear in print). https://arxiv.org/abs/0910.0577

C. Manon, Cox rings of moduli of quasi parabolic principal bundles and the K-Pieri rule, J. Comb. Theory. A 136 (2016) 1-29. https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.5666

C. Manon, Compactifications of character varieties and skein relations on conformal blocks, Geom. Dedicata. (2015), 179, 1, 335 - 376.https://arxiv.org/abs/1401.8249

 

A portion of this project lead to a collaboration with a high school student from Fairfax, VA. 

T. Faust, C. Manon, The Gorenstein property for projective coordinate rings of rank 2 parabolic vector bundles on a smooth curve. https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.00507

 

 

The connection with character varieties was developed in a series of papers, along with generalizations of work of Morgan and Shalen on the structure of "compactifications" of character varieties, this roughly means that character varieties were studied at infinity.  Aspects of the singularities of character varieties were also studied in collaboration with Lawton.  

 

C. Manon Toric geometry of free group SL2(C) character varieties from outer space, Canad. J. Math. 70 (2018), 2, 354-399. https://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0072

C. Manon, Newton-Okounkov polyhedra for character varieties and configuration spaces, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 368 (2016) 5979-6003.https://arxiv.org/abs/1403.3990

S. Lawton, C. Manon, Character varieties of free groups are Gorenstein but not always factorial, J. Algebra 456 (2016), 278-293. https://arxiv.org/abs/1504.01210

 

Technology developed for the coordinate rings of character varieties also applies much more widely to general commutative algebras of finite type. Theorems proved about their geometry also generalize and apply to spherical varieties of reductive groups.  These observations were developed in a series of collaborations with Kiumars Kaveh, Nathan Ilten, and Jessie Yang.  

 

K. Kaveh, C. Manon, Khovanskii bases, higher rank valuations, and tropical geometry. https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.00298

K. Kaveh, C. Manon, Groebner theory and tropical geometry on spherical varieties. https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.01841

K. Kaveh, C. Manon Spherical Tropical Geometry: A Survey Of Recent Developments, Acta Math. Sin. 34 (2018), 3, 454-465.

N. Ilten, C. Manon Rational Complexity-One T-Varieties are Well-Poised, Int. Math. Res. Notices. (IMRN), doi:10.1093/imrn/rnx254. https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.01629

J. Yang, C. Manon, Tropical geometry and Newton-Okounkov cones for Grassmannian of planes from compactifications. https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.06817

 

 

Toric degeneration, and more generally flat degeneration is a construction from algebraic geometry, but it turns out to have a meaning in symplectic geometry as well. This promises to be a powerful tool for studying integrable systems in symplectic manifolds.  This theory was developed in a collaboration with Joachim Hilgert and Johan Martens in the context of Hamiltonian K-spaces. 

J. Hilgert, C. Manon, J. Martens, Contraction of Hamiltonian K-spaces, Int. Math. Res. Notices. (IMRN), 20 (2017), 6255-6309. https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.06406

 

In a collaboration with Kiumars Kaveh, we developed a generalization of the classification of toric vector bundles given by Klyachko.  This is robust enough to give a classification of all toric principal bundles over toric varieties, and has connections with the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies and Bruhat-Tits buildings. 

K. Kaveh, C. Manon, Toric principal bundles, piecewise linear maps and buildings. https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.05613

 

 

In addition to developing a number of ongoing research projects with various collaborators, this project also contributed to the health and development of two math labs.  The Mason Experimental Geometry Lab (MEGL) was started by the PI and Sean Lawton and George Mason University, and continues to serve as a center for undergraduate research, mathematics visualization, and mathematics outreach in the Fairfax, VA area.  Elements and personnel of MEGL were funded by DMS 1500966 from Fall 2015 through Spring 2017.  While at George Mason, this award also funded speakers for the TADS (Topology Arithmetic Dynamics) Seminar.   In Fall 2017, the PI moved to the University of Kentucky and began the UK Math Lab, also funded in part by DMS 1500966, with a similar mission.
